caseTitle: MAJOR MAC DORBI, W. O. SAVIOUR VRS RICHARD ADOM FRIMPONG, GEORGE GYESI , MAR GEORS LTD
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana decision in Civil Appeal No. J4/45/2011, delivered on 30th January 2013, concerned a land ownership dispute between retired army officers Major Mac Dorbi and W. O. Saviour (appellants) and Richard Adom Frimpong, George Gyesi, and Mar Geors Ltd (respondents). The appellants, while in active military service in the 1980s, were allocated three swampy plots from government land through the Chief of Staff and invested significant funds in developing them. The first respondent later claimed ownership from Nii Kotey III of La and paid $20,000 to a worker, claiming joint ownership with Mac Dorbi. The High Court initially ruled for the appellants, but the Court of Appeal reversed it, citing inconsistencies in pleadings and evidence. The Supreme Court reinstated the High Court's judgment, emphasizing that the physical developments and the $20,000 payment constituted strong acknowledgments of the appellants' title. It held that procedural lapses, including W. O. Saviour's lack of formal appearance, were waived under Order 81 rules of C.I. 47 due to full participation and the principle of substantial justice. The appeal was allowed, the Court of Appeal's decision set aside, and the High Court's judgment restored.
verdict: Appeal allowed; judgment of the Court of Appeal set aside and judgment of the High Court restored.
winningSide: Appellants (Major Mac Dorbi and W. O. Saviour)
citations: Agyakuma v. Opuni (1987-88) 1 GLR 47, SC at 50
Hanna Assi v. GIHOC Refrigeration & Household Products Ltd (No.2) (2007-2008) SCGLR 16
rationaleHighlights: Undisputed physical developments on the land support appellants' claim
Payment of $20,000 by respondent acknowledged Mac Dorbi's title
Inconsistencies in evidence do not outweigh clear admissions and conduct
Appellate court should not disturb trial judge's findings where supported by evidence
Procedural defects waived under Order 81 rules due to full litigation by parties
Principle of substantial justice prevails over technicalities
Parties fully litigated ownership, validating outcome despite procedural lapses
Presumption of correctness attached to trial court's factual findings
